div.head: Title
div.p: Untitled in draft. When a revised version was published in the literary annual, Friendshipʼs Offering (see Composition and Publication), the poem first exhibited its title, “Saltzburg”; however, this title must have been determined by that of the steel engraving, which the poem was commissioned to accompany.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Ekphrastic and topographical poem.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: Draft contained in MS VIII (see Contents, list b.2).

div.head: Date
div.p: Composed probably between May and July 1834, in time for submission deadline in August. As discussed in Hanson, "Ruskin in the 1830s", W. H. Collingwood assumed incorrectly that Ruskin composed this poem during a visit to Salzburg in 1835.

div.head: Composition & Publication
div.p: Published in Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV, 317–19).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In “Ruskin in the 1830s”, Hanson argues that Collingwood wrongly assumed that Ruskin would have composed a topographical poem only about a place he had actually seen, and that therefore Ruskin must have received his commission for “Saltzburg” from Thomas Pringle, the editor of Friendshipʼs Offering, while visiting Salzburg during his familyʼs Continental tour of 1835. Not only would this alleged timing of the commission have been impossible for a text that must have been submitted for publication one year earlier, but the underlying assumption is faulty, as well. Ruskinʼs poem should not be understood in context of his aesthetic of “truth to nature” a decade later; it was commissioned, rather, in context of the print culture of illustrated travel writing. Like many other contributors to the annuals, Ruskin was responding inventively to an engraving of a foreign scene, not to the experience of the place itself.

It can be added to this argument that, in assigning this commission to the young writer, Pringle replicated an ekphrastic assignment he had given to himself four or five years earlier, as editor of Friendshipʼs Offering . . . for MDCCCXXX. That volume also featured an engraving after William Purser, the artist of Saltzburg. Entitled Spoleto and engraved by Thomas Jeavons (1795–1867), the plate may have been the first work by Purser to appear in the annual. Pringle gave himself the task of writing the accompanying text, although he had never visited the Continent, much less Spoleto, which was not well known to English travelers. In the 1820s, Mariana Starke devoted only a brief paragraph to the town, in the course of describing the route from Rome to Florence. In the 1830s, William Brockedon drew more attention to the town, highlighting the picturesque views to be discovered in the approach and surrounding countryside (Starke, Travels in Europe between the Years 1824 and 1828 [1828], 411; Brockedon, Travellerʼs Guide to Italy [1835], 144; Brockedon, Road‐Book from London to Naples, illus. Stanfield, Prout, and Brockedon [1835], 130). Even Purser probably lacked first‐hand experience of the scene, having based his drawing, according to the engravingʼs caption, on “a sketch by Captain [Robert] Melville Grindlay”, who had connections with Smith, Elder (see Chatterjee, Robert Melville; and see Smith, Elder & Company for its connections with the East India Company).

In the plate, Purser renders the scene on a plan similar to the composition of Saltzburg. Spoleto is viewed from a distant, central vantage in the countryside above the town, with the town>ʼs major monuments picked out in the middle ground. In the foreground, figures in local costume orient the spectatorʼs gaze toward the prospect. Pringleʼs accompanying text, “Spoleto”, makes no pretence of traveling farther than from the armchair. Consisting of a prose preface and a poem, the piece fills the page facing the engraving with an extract from a travel account, A Classical Tour through Italy (1813) by the Reverend John Chetwode Eustace (1761–1815), which summarizes the triumph of ancient defenders of Spoleto against invasion by Hannibalʼs army, and which highlights major monuments of the town today.

Pringle swerves from this dry annotation, however, to introduce what “will probably be esteemed by most readers [as] more interesting than pages of further details from more ordinary tourists”—some observations on Spoleto from an unpublished travel journal lent by Samuel Rogers (1763–1855). Although much briefer and less informative than the extract from Eustaceʼs published account, Rogersʼs jottings are in keeping with the governing sentiments of the literary annuals—friendship and memory. “[B]y his kind indulgence”, the “author of the ‘The Pleasures of Memory’” has shared his reminiscences of Spoleto. The quotation is a curtailed and revised version of a passage that would later be included in The Italian Journal of Samuel Rogers:

Spoleto, with its walls and turrets, soon appeared on the mountain side. . . . The gate of Hannibal [i.e., Porta Fuga]. . . . The gigantic aqueduct crossing a deep and unfathomable chasm [i.e., Ponte delle Torri]. . . . Saw it by moonlight; and its vastness and entireness, connecting us at once with some mighty and unknown people, affected me deeply.
(Friendshipʼs Offering; A Literary Album . . . for MDCCCXXX, 109; and see The Italian Journal of Samuel Rogers, ed. Hale, 205)

Pringle abridged the original passage (or perhaps Rogers did so, when presenting it to Pringle), presumably in order to heighten the closing poetic sentence—an evocation of the scene by moonlight, with a meditation on history. In the poem that follows these prose extracts, after an ekphrastic description of the scene for which Eustaceʼs account is serviceable, it is Rogers“s sentiment that frames the speakerʼs reflections, as he positions himself in the classic pose of a figure in a prospect poem:

lg.l: Spoleto! midst thy hills and storied piles,
Thy classic haunts and legendary aisles,
ʼTwere sweet, methinks, ere life hath passed away,
To spend one long, reflective summerʼs day;
Beneath those quiet shades my limbs to cast,
And muse oʼer all that links thee to the past;
To linger on, through twilightʼs wizard hour,
Till the wan moon gleamed high oʼer rock and tower,
And, with her necromantic lustre strange,
Lit up the landscape with a solemn change—
Gilding its grandeur into sad relief,
Like a pale widow stately in her grief.

div.p:
The pose and meditation are conventional, but the additional frame of Rogersʼs shared reflections adds the theme of friendship, rendering this ekphrastic travel piece peculiarly appropriate to the literary annual. Friendship is brought forward explicitly in the conclusion of the poem, as Pringle pays tribute to one “Whom ʼtis a pride and grace to call my Friend”. At the same time, the poet/speaker qualifies this friendship as unequal, as he subordinates himself to Rogersʼs fame. The speaker self‐consciously acknowledges that his meditation on the prospect is indebted to the scene that, as described in the journal, once “rose . . . on Rogersʼ classic eye”; and he pays deference to the elder poetʼs greater capacity to encompass such a view, for “[h]ad he to verse transferred it [the scene] from his mind”, the “touching image” would have been “enshrined” and “embalmed in words that could ne“er die”. Word and image may be joined equally as Sister Arts in the literary annual, but not poets. Whereas Rogersʼs poetry was destined to be “embalmed”, “Far other fate awaits this rustic lay, / Framed for the passing purpose of a day”. While the scrap from Rogersʼs journal carries the literary annualʼs stock themes of memory and fellow‐feeling, Friendshipʼs Offering nonetheless maintains the neoclassical ordering of the arts, bringing Pringleʼs own “Spoleto” comfortably down to its proper level.
it also installs the literary annual“s version of the neoclassical ordering of the arts, restraining its ambitions to affect the reader for purposes of a passing day, not the eternity of fame. ,

Four years later, when Pringle had another plate by Purser, Saltzburg, to assign to a writer for the upcoming volume for 1835, he chose Ruskin in spite of the youth's lack of professional experience, in part because the editor was impressed by the youth's ability to match words with pictures, but also because behind the scene he could dedicate the assignment as an act of friendship. Since it was at about this time that Pringle arranged for Ruskin to be introduced to Samuel Rogers, and escorted him to Rogers's St. James Place residence (Hanson, Ruskin in the 1830s, 000; Samuel Rogers), it is more probable that Pringle would have invested the "Saltzburg" commission with greater significance than the mere happenstance that W. G. Collingwood supposes--that "[i]t happened that Mr. Pringle had a plate of Salzburg which he wanted to print in order to make up the volume of Friendship's Offering for the next Christmas" (Life and Work of John Ruskin, 1:52). Rather, in conferring such an impressive commission on a fifteen-year-old first-time contributor, Pringle would have shown his regard for the Ruskin family, and formalized his role of mentor and friend to the young poet, just as Rogers had condescended to Pringle. A tribute to an elder and greater poet occupies the entirety of Pringle's conclusion of his poem on Spoleto, framing the ekphrasis as an offering to a lasting poet from the pages of an ephemeral publication, "Framed for the passing purpose of a day" in the calendar of an annual, by a "rustic" Scots poet:

About four years later, when Pringle had another plate by Purser, Saltzburg, to assign for the upcoming volume for 1835, one can only speculate whether, in bestowing that significant opportunity on a (practically) unpublished fifteen-year old, he imagined himself replicating the patronage by the senior man of letters that. If so, did Pringle cast Ruskin as the lesser talent, or merely less experienced? The one certainty is that Pringle premised his bid for the reader's friendship on his humility. The conclusion to “Spoleto”, consists of an offering to a lasting poet from the pages of an ephemeral publication, “Framed for the passing purpose of a day” in the calendar of an annual, by a “rustic” Scots poet:

lg.l: So rose the scene [of Spoleto] on Rogers' classic eye
And thus, embalmed in words that ne'er could die,
Its touching image had remained enshrined,
Had he to verse transferred it from his mind.
Far other fate awaits this rustic lay,
Framed for the passing purpose of a day:
Enough for me if he its tone commend
Whom 'tis a pride and grace to call my Friend.

div.p: (Friendshipʼs Offering; A Literary Album . . . for MDCCCXXX, 111).

Lines from Pringle's "Spoleto" are possibly echoed by Ruskin in "Saltzburg".

The extract first highlights the town's fame for repulsing an attack by Hannibal's army, following the Cathaginian victory over Rome, a continuing source of local pride which is mentioned in all guidebooks. The passage then scans the town's major monuments, using a strategy that may have been instructive to Ruskin. As a Roman Catholic priest, Eustace dwells on the Gothic cathedral, of course admiring its beauty in contrast with lighting its lurid fascination as Ruskin does; however, the passage also presents views of the cathedral that are invisible in the plate, such as details from its interior, and the prospect looking outward from its terrace. This accidental juxtaposition of conflicting viewpoints may have given; the "barbarous antiquity" of its castle (see Eustace, A Classical Tour through Italy, 1:177-79).
